pros: international, a lot of challenge, learning a lot, trainings

pros: Proud to work in big 4

cons:
- Work-life balance varies hugely depending on department and time of year
- Despite being in a country with 3 official languages, it's very French-heavy and it seems easier to get promoted and win favour if you are a French native speaker; Germans and others have to work harder to get to the same place due to different working culture.
- English is the main communication language within the firm, but the quality of English is really bad in internal messages. procedures etc. and even some external documents for paying clients. Many senior people think that their English is better than it really is, and ignore the internal translators (native English speakers) or don't even consult them.
post_title: Excellent place to be during Covid; good employer overall
pros:
- Excellent overall management during Covid: encouraged to work at home, no pressure to come to the office when not necessary, mental health initiatives, online sports/yoga sessions etc., regular catch-up sessions with CEO, no one has lost their job due to Covid, and bonus + 13th salary were still paid in 2020
- Free iPhone with generous data and minutes allowance - no need for a personal phone -> big cost saving in everyday life
- Bonus every June (at least 1 month's salary) and 13th month salary paid in December
- Sleek, comfortable offices
- Nice canteen
- Good concierge service with loads of services to make your personal life easier: car washing, dry-cleaning, Christmas tree ordering, shoe repairs, flowers, and more
- Fantastic Christmas programme, including free Christmas market and a family day on Saturdays with lots of fun for kids (obviously didn't happen in 2020)

cons: lots of work, salary increase not attractive

date_and_job: Jun 18, 2017 - Senior Tax Advisor in Luxembourg
pros: International environment, flexible work conditions

cons: Hierarchical structure, high expectations in terms of workload and pace, a lot depends on the partner in charge of your area
pros: Working with smart and motivated people, access to an impressive knowledge base, great internal programmes for developing softskills and management skills, excellent reputation in the market

cons:
Turning down other offers, I believed in the spirit of the Big 4. Starting straight from university, I was motivated to start at a world known and well-respected company. 

In the intro month, they were swearing on an environment full of team orientation and coaching. Quickly, I realized that people weren't putting effort to help you out, instead you were rather being thrown into cold water.  
Instead, they were pressuring for perfection from you after explaining to you things once (being with the company about 6 weeks at that time). If you dare to ask second questions for further understandings, that would be discussed on your feedback as negative review (such as "he isn't capable of understanding"). 

During my work I experienced seniors acting as managers, writing reviews which I couldn't do any more besides shaking my head about, such as "he/ she didn't mark something in yellow". Other seniors copying and pasting the same reviews into multiple feedbacks multiple times, regardless whether your knowledge and working hours for the company you were auditing was 50, 150 or 250 hours. Trying to  explain this to your reviewer (a manager), who is suppose to help you out and the only thing he says is “They are allowed to write whatever they want”, meanwhile me trying to explain that the knowledge and quality of someone’s work isn’t the same and rather improves, enhances and quickens if someone spends 50 hours on the project, or when someone has worked 150 hours, and again if someone has worked for 250 hours in the same project.

I experienced higher level employees acting as seniors, trying to pressure you, asking for things that really don't make sense at all, and ask you again to fix them the way you were thinking before, and at the end of engagement putting on your feedbacks that you are taking too much time to do your work. 

The CEO had inserted overtime to be approved by manager in 2016: With that in mind, I had directors and managers coming to me at 16:00 asking me for things that needed to be finished for the next day call with client at 9am, which leads to working some 3-5 hours over time. None of these hours were allowed to be charged. 
Other managers were only giving the time they had to be charged as overtime to certain seniors/friends only. 

At the very end, it comes down to sympathy and empathy towards to who you are working with. If you are lucky and you happen to work with someone you get along with, then you are sorted. Otherwise, it’s a lot of biting your teeth together and pray that the engagement is over sooner rather than later and you don’t have to work with this person again anymore. I experienced PwC as an injustice rather employer, where I saw people freaking out, crying, losing it (list can go on) in front you, witnessing discrimination towards your background and strictly showing within the team who their favorite is and who is somewhat worthless towards them. Would I ever do it again? Definitely no.

pros:
Big firm with a worlwide network, great infrastructure, a lot of diversity.
Evolutions, quality of learning and nice benefits (cell phone, leasing car, health care...)

cons:
Promotion is based on obsequiousness, cheating, deception, falsehood and a lot of politics...
Skilled consultants (e.g. juniors, seniors) get nonsense reasons for not getting the well-deserved promotions.
PwC actually needs skilled people to remain on low positions just to keep low hourly rate for the firm's profits.
Very often, managers take the credit of theam members' good work instead of recognizing the merits of those who actually did the job and acclain themselves subject matter experts, when in fact they only scratch the surface of that specific matter.
Tully skilled people are not involved in projects from the very beginning, but rather when things start getting messy in the project and there is high risk that customers might be unsatisfied...
pros:
Populistic actions (e.g. parties, events, lunches, etc.) which some of the naive juniors take for granted... and get brain-washed.
This company is cashcow... it will undertake any business activity that brings money for the least effort and risk, and then, once it stops being profitable, it will shift right to the next profitable one.

cons: There are some very brainwashed employees who have given their lives to the company for 15, 20, 30 years etc. Have the slightest chat or laugh and they will glare at you as if you are a traitor, making the office environment stale. The culture is to blame the junior employees and the partners are above the law. Once I told a partner about an important mistake he had made in a document, he replied to me that I should have spotted it earlier - i.e. partners never responsible if things go wrong. Also the salary is low for Luxembourg - I moved now to a more junior role that pays more.

pros: I've need to find a job with regular clock

cons: Although there are a number of cultures, the french-speaking cultures are dominant.  In general, I found the French and Germans associated with people similar to them although the office does have a number of cultures represented.  I also found that decisions for promotions were very arbitrary (and often on cultural lines).
date_and_job: Jul 26, 2014 - Corporate Tax Advisor in Luxembourg
pros: The work was very interesting - although Luxembourg is rarely leading large projects, it often is involved as an intermediary between other larger locations like the US and UK.  Great development opportunities, even if for a couple of years.

cons:
Overall...a company best avoided. You do not want to work here. 

The management here pursue their staff aggressively and their business development opportunities weakly.

There is a also a very strong 'blame the junior staff' culture, and a very high tendency to exploit the staff as much as possible.

Many very destructive senior management figures are indulged.  There is a lot of blatant bullying.

If you bring a problem to HR, then you are the problem.  It's best not to involve them.

If you are offered a job here, make enquiries about the partners AND directors in charge of the business line you will be in.  Luxembourg is a small place and people are well known.  If you get negative feedback, stay where you are.

If you end up working here out of necessity, plan your exit from day one.

I have been working for a wage for over two decades - sad to say, but this was by far the worst company I was ever in.
post_title: Regarded as the worst of the Big 4 in Luxembourg by those in the know.
pros: To be clear, the culture of the consulting line of business is set by the partner in charge, so there are good and bad areas of the company.  The good include IT and some areas of regulatory. If you get into this firm under a good line of management, you can have an ok-to-good career, depending on your aspirations and what you want out of life.  In that respect, PwC Luxembourg might be okay.

cons: There is nothing to complain about.

date_and_job: Apr 13, 2012 - Audit Senior Manager in Luxembourg
pros:
One of the best reason to work for PwC is that you have a clear view on your career plan for the first 6-8 years in the firm. After that, it becomes extremely hazy. 
Another positive point is that there are real opportunities for international mobility around the globe, for people who love travelling and relocating in foreign countries.
Last obvious reason is that you meet and work with a lot of different people and clients from various horizons.

cons: Lack of work life balance
